_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Computer controls to detect normal operation deviation, includes monitoring of flow, pressure, and tank level
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Prevention Program outlined here covers the ammonia (conc 20% or greater) system from truck unloading, storage, transfer, and fermentation operations.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Danisco US, Inc.

DuPont Industrial Biosciences (IB)

Risk Management Plan - Program 3

 

Introduction



Danisco US Inc, a Subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, (formerly Genencor) is an industrial biotechnology facility that manufactures industrial enzymes.  The facility is located on the southwest side of Cedar Rapids, Iowa at the intersection of 41st Avenue Drive and C Street Southwest.  This ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 certified facility employs 186 people and operates under a team-based organizational structure.



The facility manufactures enzymes, fermentates, and whole cells for food, animal feed, and industrial use through a fermentation based process.  Enzymes are chemicals comprised of large proteins and have been used in the food and detergent manufacturing industries for many years.  The facility's enzyme products are available in liquid or granular form.  The facility operates a continuous 24-hour-per-day process and has maintenance and laboratory support.  Support staff includes site management, safety, health and environmental (SHE), engineering, purchasing, finance, and systems personnel.



Ammonium hydroxide is the regulated substance under EPA Risk Management criteria.  The enzyme manufacturing process requires the use of ammonium hydroxide at 29.9% concentration.  Maximum on-site storage of ammonium hydroxide solution is approximately 130,000 liters.  The ammonium hydroxide Risk Management Program (RMP) covers ammonium hydroxide unloading operations, storage, transfer, and fermentation operations.



Chemical Safety



The site's overall approach to chemical safety is comprehensive.  Systems are engineered with safety and environmental aspects in mind, with input from all affected areas of the plant prior to construction or use.  The goal is to provide a safe workplace while minimizing environmental impact.  Release prevention methods are implemented where possible, including automation, containment of all outdoor ta

nks and indoor sump areas, and on-site air scrubbing and neutralization capabilities.



The site management team is committed to the implementation and success of site safety, health and environmental programs and goals. 



The safety, health and environmental budget is established to provide:

?    Appropriate and adequate personal protective equipment

?    Appropriate and post-offer and annual medical examinations

?    Training

?    Industrial hygiene monitoring equipment and analysis

?    Hazardous waste pick-up for a conditionally exempt small quantity hazardous waste generator

?    Emergency response team equipment and supplies



A site Safety Committee is in place to foster the plant's overall safety performance.  The Committee includes members from all areas of the plant, and is led by the site SHE department to ensure employee safety concerns are heard and addressed.



The site SHE Policy lends guidance to site efforts.



Cedar Rapids SHE Policy:

Using our expertise in modern biotechnology, Danisco US, Inc. seeks to become a leader in sustainability.  Through innovation and collaboration we will protect the environment, promote the well-being of our employees and the world community.



In the spirit of this intent, we will organize our work activities to improve continually in SHE management, performance and pollution prevention.  We will meet legal and internal requirements, prevent pollution and preserve resources. We are committed to the prevention of injury and ill health of our employees.  Progress will be monitored and communicated to our employees, and we will use their input to improve our performance.



We understand that the long-term viability and progress of our business depends on us continuing to take responsibility for improving the environmental, social and economic conditions resulting from our commercial activities.



New employees attend approximately 14 hours of initial SHE training, which includes chemical safety as well as various OSHA and

EPA covered programs.  Job duty training is ongoing for each employee and occurs with co-worker trainers utilizing on the job observation and partnering, SOPs, training assessments, and computer based training programs.  DuPont believes in being proactive in its training endeavors and strives to encourage employees to attend specific training associated with their job duties that goes above and beyond basic job requirements.



Capital projects deemed necessary for safety, health and environmental reasons are implemented and supported through the DuPont capital expenditure process.



Emergency Response



The site Emergency Action Plan (EH-Protocol-026) addresses how employees shall respond to emergencies, including hazardous weather, fire, medical, building evacuation, hazardous device threat, utility failure, and hazardous material spills.  All employees are trained in the site Emergency Action Plan as part of the established initial safety training for new employees.



The Emergency Action Plan also introduces the function and responsibilities of the site Emergency Response Team (ERT).  ERT members are trained in Fire Extinguisher Use, Operations Level Industrial Chemical Spill Response, First Aid/Adult CPR, Automatic External Defibrillator, and Bloodborne Pathogens. 



This group trains annually as well as conducts drills and tabletop scenarios to prepare for incident handling.  On-site ERT equipment is maintained to support the ERT efforts.  The team partners with the Cedar Rapids Fire Department and HazMat Team with regards to chemical spill preparation and response.  The primary focus of the site ERT in the event of a chemical spill is to assess the situation, notify emergency services, evacuate and account for all employees and provide support to emergency responders as needed.  The onsite team only responds to the level of their training.



The site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release (ERP; EH-Protocol-017) is in place to provide E

RT guidance for spill operations.  The Incident Command System is the designated management system for emergencies and is included in the plan.  The plan outlines the responsibility of involved personnel during an incident, discusses the Incident Command System, gives instruction for securing outside emergency assistance, addresses internal and external notifications including the media and public, outlines emergency procedures for general emergency response, addresses spill control/personal protective equipment/first aid, and covers disposal and decontamination.  All ERT members are trained in the site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release on an annual basis.  The site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release is shared with the Cedar Rapids Fire Department and Linn County Local Emergency Planning Committee.



General Prevention Measures



Danisco, Cedar Rapids has a number of measures in place for spill prevention.  These include, but are not limited to an in-depth preventative maintenance program tracked using SAP, standard operating procedures which are updated at least annually, employee training, back-up equipment where possible, computer monitored level indicators with interlocking systems when process limits are reached, and containment basins.  The facility has 24-hour team-based operations coverage in the facility.  The facility also operates under ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 certifications which ensure that proper document control is in place.



The presence of an Emergency Response Team on all shifts ensures that all safety and environmental events are addressed immediately to prevent the escalation of an incident if possible.



Five Year Accident History



The DuPont, Cedar Rapids Facility has had one incident in the last 5-years involving the ammonia hydroxide system that resulted in on-site or off-site impacts.

?    3/18/2015 there was a release on-site that led to the release of 55 lb. of ammonia.  As a result of the

release, there were two other medical treatment cases.

Changes to Improve Safety



As part of an on-going safety review, a multi-session Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted for the site ammonia hydroxide  system between August 2013 and April 2014.  This was led by the site Process Safety Management (PSM) Leader, who is trained internally by DuPont to lead PHAs.  The PHA included a team of DuPont IB, Cedar Rapids members representing Logistics (process), Fermentation (process), Maintenance, Engineering, and SHE.  Five recommendations for investigation and improvement were generated from the Process Hazard Analysis.  The action items and their follow-up actions can be found in G:\Environmental\Risk Management Plan\HAZOPs and PHAs \2014_PHA_Report_New_System.  All action items are to be completed by September 1, 2014
